review_title: Good first step, but very location dependant experience
pros:
* The benefits structure helps young or recently moved people to establish themselves with a lot less hassle than having to do it all yourself.
* Unless you work at some crazy busy location and never get a second to go to back, you'll never be dehydrated at work.
* Upward momentum is better than most service industry positions. Moving up isn't exactly "easy" because there's obviously always fewer positions as you go up the hierarchy, but between the constant expansion and typical churn there's more available than you'd think.

Neither pro nor con: As typical for any large chains, store level culture is heavily dependent on your manager and coworkers. Every location I've worked at has had friendly if stressed coworkers, but I've also definitely seen other stores have horror stories. Go with your gut.
cons:
Customer base is shifting in expectations and brand identity is stuck in a limbo between wanting to maintain "independent cafe" quality and intimacy but "fast food" scale and quantity. This means:
* You will get complaints from customers for not making a heavily modified blended drink as quickly as a brewed coffee, and then complained to again if you accidentally miss a step or eyeball a measurement for speed.
* You will be measured by corporate against drive thru times while at the same time being expected to connect and have genuine conversations with every single one of your customers.
* You will probably be understaffed and not exactly surrounded by passion. You care enough to look at reviews on Glassdoor, but your high school grad coworker who's just saving up over summer for college sure doesn't care that much.
* Much of the "skilled" barista work is automated out (grind and shots are fully automatic, and steaming milk is semi-automatic) or discouraged for time (don't expect to refine your latte art during a rush).
* People will not engage with you or learn anything about even their own orders, and if you try to explain even basic concepts or help them ask for even simple drinks they will ignore you or forget every single time. You will be asked if a latte can come with milk in it at least once a week.
* Nobody will care that even when the store is physically empty, you still have mobile and uber orders. This is true across all food service, but Starbucks get a particularly high number of commuters who do NOT understand that if they are late to work because they went to a Starbucks during rush hour, it is their own fault.

pros: Starbucks is a fairly good company to work for. Their customers in general are nice and tip well. They are usually hiring and have good hours normally.
cons: Management is a nightmare. They are constantly shifting people around and don’t seem to fire bad managers no matter how inept. Working any minimum wage job you will be surrounded by some people with no ambition in life other than to smoke weed and clock out. If you put in even 50% effort you will end up caring the team. It’s okay to start work there as a young fledgling adult but do not stay there for longer than 3-5 years. Don’t yet looped into thinking it’s a career, store managers make around 60k if they’re lucky. There are tons of other jobs that you can make more at while not wanting to blow your brains out.

The store I work at doesn’t care about making quality beverages, but rather prioritizes super sugary speedily made drinks. The espresso machines are completely automated, never calibrated, and constantly dribble water and spit espresso when shots are pulled. Milk steaming is also automated by letting it sit on the espresso machine bar. The blended drinks are made with vast amounts of sugar, corn syrup, and other unrecognizable ingredients.
When quality is replaced with speed no-one wins!

review_title: Don't get me wrong: you can pay some of your bills
pros: - Potential to work with kind, generous people (I was fortunate!)
cons:
What a painfully insincere company. If you're an average person, you likely don't know that this corporation touts their excellence in creating a "third-place" for visitors, wherein a "first-place" is defined as home and a "second-place" is defined as [the visitor's] place of work. On surface level, this seems like a great idea. However, the shine that this company does work to maintain to the public eye is little more than veneer. My co-workers and I struggled to pay rent and with our mental health -- it's pretty taxing to have a corporation spewing "third place" ideals to the visitor they seek to inappropriately accommodate* while short-staffing their workers and timing out shifts such that breaks aren't necessary. (*Have you any idea the number of times someone would hand their drink to an empty-handed friend before asking for a remake and to keep the "incorrectly made" drink their friend was now sipping? Make a big enough stink and they'd get a $4 giftcard, too.)

TDLR:
- Short-staffing; told "earn the extra labor". If criteria to "earn" the help is met, the help is neither staffed nor additionally hired.
- Minimum wage
- Corporate affirms "customer is always right" mentality to an inappropriate degree

review_title: Pretty okay if you're in college
pros:
*Tips are collective and based on hours per week

*Managers are more understanding than other jobs

*Your teammates can vote for who is partner of the quarter and you get a small bonus with that

*The training is as good as it can be given everything you need to learn

*30 minute break is required if you work 6 or more hours

* You also get a 10 minute break no matter how long your shift is
cons:
*Customers can be really nasty and creepy (stalking a lot of the female workers, peeing on the walls in the bathroom, getting mad that some stores give personal discounts and others don't)

*I lost my partner during covid and because we weren't married I wasn't allowed anytime off by corporate standards

*Pay isn't anywhere near enough for all that you do. Had to pick up a second job to pay my rent

*They don't do the quarterly pay increase like they are supposed to

*The amount of information you have to memorize quickly and take from training and apply to everything else is a lot and can be overwhelming. A lot of people will quit because they don't understand how difficult it will be (this is mainly if you have a busy store like I did)

*Sometimes managers will try to keep you on the floor by giving you a 15 minute break instead of your full 30

*Starbucks will value partners that have been there for a while over you. We had a partner that had been there for over 15 years, but he would inappropriately touch and talk to the female workers. We complained about it to management a lot, but Starbucks only does has repercussions if you directly report to the DM which a lot of girls didn't feel comfortable with (you don't get to talk to the district manager much). He never got fired and our manager kept saying it was because they had to build a case on him because he'd been there for a while.

*Moving up at Starbucks is a bit hard because the company can be a bit clicky. Since there werent that many boys who worked at Starbucks they usually would get promoted quicker than the girls who had been there longer/were strong workers

*Starbucks will always side with shifts over you. When I first started there was a girl who bullied a lot of people but she reported me as not doing what she wanted. When I was asked about it I and a few other people said I did what she asked, I just asked why. I got written up for it

pros:
The people are amazing
Great team atmosphere 
Great learning about coffee and history of the brand
Develop Great customer relationships 
Loved the ethos behind creating the 'third place
cons:
It's not what it was. People don't tend to stay anymore. Typically new starters last a month and leave meaning its harder for us that have been there longest.
Delivery services are ruining the customer experience.. customers in store now have to wait because we don't have enough bars to serve drive thru, cafe and delivery and we have to apologise constantly. Another issue is recent technology upgrades  were buggy and has made things difficult... customers were not happy and we didn't get a lot of support dealing with the complaints. 
We rarely get feedback about our performance, except if something goes wrong. Very little encouragement to progress or develop. 
Job feels monotonous after a while, the busy pace means you don't have the time to develope those great customer moments we used to have... now its more about getting the queues through quickly.
Also new training is all on apps which we are expected to do in our own time, if we don't we get in trouble.

review_title: Sets the bar for minimum wages job but can hire crappy people
pros:
Benefits are great when compared to other minimum wage fast-food jobs.

Upward mobility is pretty simple, fast, and driven based on your personal dedication.

They have an online college program that helps you get your first bachelor's degree in a variety of fields.

Often coworkers are nice and work morale is good.

The real culture of welcoming to all people and of service.
cons:
The dress code is kind of silly, hypocritical, and frankly based on a lot of racial profiling ideas.

They call us partners but we can't even make the company add-on tipping to debit cards.

No gratuity or profit-sharing even though their products are based a lot on worker skill and craftsmanship rather than speed like at a Mcdonald's. We deserve to make a genuine cut of the profits or at least gratuity because generally, drinks require more work than you're ever trained for. We can make a hundred custom complex drinks and still make the same rate which means our wage is worth less the more drinks we make and the more work they require.

I've worked at three different stores and each store had at least 1-2 group of people that often had a leadership role but also had a very toxic personality. Having too much dependance on shift leads at the cost of employee morale.

Customers can often treat you like crap and like you're beneath them. It's Starbucks and it's expensive, so you meet a lot of snobby rich people who won't even tip. (Hence the need for profit sharing and gratuity to make employee morale better when dealing with snobby people which also incentivizes upselling and making complex drinks that cost more)

Overall the worst part about this company is the facade of a caring and welcoming company but in reality only your coworkers show true care about you not the actual corporation. They give you silly benefits like a free subscription to Spotify or limit you to specific services like ASU or Lyra which sure is free college and free mental healthcare (at least the first 20 visits are) but what would actually help is giving employees a real cut of the enourmous amounts of money we make them so we can afford to choose which school we want to go too, choose our own mental healthcare providers and overall afford to live in general. This would show real care if we were ACTUAL partners who made ACTUAL cuts of the business or at least gratuity, which would incentivize workers to work harder, upsell and overall care for the business and feel cared for by the business.

review_title: It is a lot of work but can be alright
pros:
There are plenty of people to interact and make friends with. (Mostly employees, occasionally the customers). 

The tips can be nice, about extra $1 per hour.

Free drinks during shift and a food item.

Depending on the store, theyll let you take "expired" food. It usually doesnt expire for a week
cons:
Work you extremely hard if at a drive through. The cafe stores arent too bad to work at.

The customers can be extremely rude

Dont train very well at certain stores and expect you to. get it immediately 

Closing shifts suck at busy drive through stores, you sometimes have to stay pretty late after your shift (I had stayed until 1 am a few times)
